title: Normal Hearing with Tinnitus (Left Acoustic Neuroma)
chief_complaint: I have reduced hearing in my left ear that started suddenly during my pregnancy. I hear okay one-on-one, but I struggle in noisy places, and I have a high-pitched ringing and sensitivity to loud sounds in that ear.

problem_summary.onset: Sudden onset during the first trimester of pregnancy.
problem_summary.course: Stable pure tone sensitivity but persistent tinnitus and difficulty in noise.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: High-pitched tinnitus, loudness intolerance (hyperacusis), difficulty hearing in noise.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Difficulty following conversations in noisy or adverse listening conditions.

history.present_illness: Patient reported sudden reduced hearing in the left ear during pregnancy. She denies dizziness, vertigo, otalgia, otorrhea, or aural fullness.
history.otologic_history: History of Bell's palsy on the left side a few months prior to pregnancy (fully recovered).
history.patient_goals: Diagnosis and management of tinnitus and hearing difficulty.

tests.name: Otoscopy
tests.key_findings: Clear ear canals and intact tympanic membranes bilaterally.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Normal thresholds in both ears. However, the left ear thresholds are slightly worse (10-20 dB HL) compared to the right ear (0-10 dB HL), particularly at 2000, 4000, and 8000 Hz where there is a slight asymmetry.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Speech Recognition Thresholds (SRTs) align with pure tone averages; good test reliability.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Not conducted due to patient reports of loudness intolerance.

tests.name: Otoacoustic Emissions (TEOAE)
tests.key_findings: Robust emissions in both ears, suggesting normal outer hair cell function.

tests.name: TEN (Threshold Equalizing Noise) Test
tests.key_findings: Abnormal results in the left ear suggesting cochlear dead regions or neural dysfunction. Right ear results were normal.

numeric_results.RE_Masked_Thresholds: 50 dB HL at all freqs (0.5-4.0 kHz)

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.key_findings: Right ear showed normal peak and interpeak latencies. Left ear showed absence of wave V at 70 dBnHL.

tests.name: MRI
tests.key_findings: Large acoustic neuroma on the left cerebellar pontine (CP) angle compressing the brainstem and VIIIth cranial nerve.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with clinically normal pure-tone thresholds bilaterally, though slight asymmetry is noted in the high frequencies (left worse than right). Despite normal sensitivity and robust OAEs, the patient exhibits significant functional deficits including tinnitus and loudness intolerance. Advanced diagnostic testing revealed retrocochlear pathology: the TEN test indicated neural dysfunction/dead regions in the left ear, and ABR showed an absent Wave V. MRI confirmed a large left-sided acoustic neuroma.
counseling_points: Although your hearing test shows 'normal' ability to hear quiet beeps, your difficulty hearing in noise and the ringing in your ear are real and caused by a growth on your hearing nerve.
The MRI confirmed a tumor called an acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma) on the left side, which is pressing on the nerve.
This pressure on the nerve explains why you have trouble processing speech in noise even though the ear organ itself (the cochlea) is working well.
We will refer you to a neurotologist to discuss management options, which may include microsurgery or stereotactic radiosurgery.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is confused because they can hear fine in quiet rooms but struggle significantly in noise.
Emphasize the sudden onset during pregnancy.
Mention that loud sounds are physically uncomfortable (loudness intolerance/hyperacusis) in the left ear.
